Legal_Issue: Validity of the '637 Patent and whether Apotex's formulation infringes it
Evidence_Assessment: Expert evidence on technical feasibility of avoiding pink hue by eliminating water
Decision_Outcome: '637 Patent found invalid due to anticipation; infringement established if valid
Burden_of_Proof: On SmithKline to justify injunction; on Apotex to challenge validity
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony on pharmaceutical formulation and prior art interpretation
Legal_Rule: A patent must be novel, non-obvious, and useful; novelty under Section 28.2(1), obviousness under Section 28.3
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and factual assessment based on balance of probabilities
Procedural_Issue: Application for prohibition order against regulatory approval
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of '637 Patent by Apotex's generic paroxetine tablets
Review_Standard: Interpretation of Patent Act and examination of prior art ('060 Patent)
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Fair hearing provided in pre-approval dispute
Key_Evidence_Considered: Disclosure in '060 Patent; expert analysis on solving pink hue issue
Legal_Framework: Regulatory and patent law framework governing drug approval and patent protection
Applicant_Challenge: SmithKline challenged Health Canada's potential approval of Apotex's generic
Defendant_Response: Apotex alleged non-infringement and invalidity of the '637 Patent
Remedy_Requested: Order prohibiting Health Canada from approving Apotex's application
Decision_Authority: Federal Court or relevant Canadian court with jurisdiction
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial determination on validity and infringement
Legal_Provision: Section 28.2(1), Section 28.3 of the Patent Act
Applicable_Process: Notice of Compliance (NOC) proceedings under Canadian patent linkage regime
Outcome_of_Review: Invalidity established, no stay of approval issued
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Application for prohibition order pending decision
Governing_Rule: Patent Act provisions on novelty and obviousness
